Sample Question: How do I file a claim?
Keywords: fnol, first notice, loss, report claim, file claim, new claim, start claim, how to claim, initiate claim, submit claim, make a claim, open claim
Answer: To file a First Notice of Loss (FNOL), follow these steps: 1) Contact your insurance provider within 30 days of the incident (72 hours for catastrophic events). 2) Provide required information: policyholder name, policy number, date/time of incident, location, and description of loss. 3) Document the damage with photographs and written descriptions. 4) Obtain a claim reference number from the representative. 5) Follow up with any additional documentation requested. The FNOL can be submitted via Phone (1-800-555-CLAIM), Online portal, Mobile app, or Through an authorized agent. Processing typically begins within 24-48 hours of submission.

Keywords: deductible, out of pocket, pay before, how much pay, deductible amount, what is deductible, deductible work, deductible mean
Answer: A deductible is the amount you pay out-of-pocket before your insurance coverage applies. Types of Deductibles: Fixed Dollar Deductible (a set amount per claim e.g. $500 $1000 $2500), Percentage Deductible (calculated as a percentage of insured value typically 1-5% common for wind/hail damage), Annual Aggregate Deductible (once your total deductibles in a year reach the aggregate amount the insurer covers all remaining claims in full). Key Points: Higher deductibles = lower premium costs but more out-of-pocket during a claim. The deductible is subtracted from your claim payment. Different coverage types may have different deductible amounts. Review your policy declarations page for your specific deductible amounts.

Keywords: coverage, what is covered, types of coverage, policy cover, insurance cover, what does my policy, dwelling, personal property, liability
Answer: Standard insurance policies include several types of coverage: Dwelling Coverage (A) protects the physical structure of your insured property. Personal Property Coverage (B) covers your belongings within the property. Liability Coverage (C) protects against lawsuits for bodily injury or property damage you cause. Additional Living Expenses (D) covers temporary housing if your property becomes uninhabitable. Each coverage type has specific limits and deductibles outlined in your policy declarations page. You can often adjust these limits based on your needs and budget. Note: Some perils require additional endorsements (e.g. flood earthquake).

Sample Question: What exclusions does my policy have?
Keywords: exclusion, not covered, excluded, what isn't covered, what is not covered, limitation, doesn't cover, won't cover
Answer: Standard policies typically exclude the following: Flood damage (requires separate flood insurance), Earthquake damage (available as an endorsement), Intentional damage by the policyholder, Normal wear and tear, Pest infestations (termites rodents etc.), Nuclear hazards, Acts of war, Government actions, Business-related losses (requires commercial coverage). It is strongly recommended that policyholders review exclusions carefully and consider additional endorsements for comprehensive protection. Speak with your agent about coverage gaps specific to your situation.

Sample Question: How long does a claim take?
Keywords: claim status, how long, timeline, when will, claim take, processing time, waiting, update on claim, claim progress
Answer: Claims processing timelines vary by complexity: Simple Property Claims take 5-10 business days, Auto Claims take 10-15 business days, Complex Liability Claims take 30-60 business days. Regulatory Requirements: Acknowledgment of claim within 15 days of receipt. Decision on claim within 30 days of receiving all documentation. Payment within 30 days of claim approval. An adjuster is assigned within 24 hours of FNOL and will make initial contact within 48 hours. You can check your claim status through the online portal or by contacting your assigned adjuster directly.

Sample Question: What if my claim is denied?
Keywords: appeal, dispute, denied, deny, rejected, disagree, overturn, challenge, fight, unfair
Answer: If your claim has been denied you have several options. Internal Appeals Process: 1) Submit a written appeal within 60 days of the claim decision. 2) Include additional documentation or evidence supporting your case. 3) A senior adjuster (not involved in the original decision) reviews the appeal. 4) Response within 30 days of receiving the appeal. If Internal Appeal is Denied: Pursue external arbitration. File a complaint with your state Department of Insurance. Request an independent appraisal for property damage disputes. A written explanation of any denial must include the specific policy provisions relied upon and you must be informed of your right to appeal.

Sample Question: What are insurance fraud red flags?
Keywords: fraud, suspicious, red flag, fake claim, fraudulent, scam, dishonest
Answer: Insurance fraud red flags include: Claims filed shortly after policy inception or coverage increase. Multiple claims in a short period. Claimant is overly pushy about quick settlement. Inconsistent or changing account of events. Injuries inconsistent with the described accident. Claimant has financial difficulties. Witnesses are friends or family members. Damage pattern inconsistent with described incident. Reluctance to provide recorded statements. When two or more red flags are present the case is referred to the Special Investigations Unit (SIU). Confirmed fraud cases are reported to the National Insurance Crime Bureau (NICB) and criminal prosecution may be pursued for claims exceeding $5000.

Keywords: subrogation, recovery, third party, someone else fault, other driver, at fault, reimbursement, get money back, deductible back
Answer: Subrogation is the process where your insurance company seeks reimbursement from a responsible third party after paying your claim. How It Works: 1) Your insurer pays your claim. 2) The insurer determines a third party is at fault. 3) The insurer pursues the third party (or their insurer) for recovery. 4) Recovery amounts are split: insurer gets the claim amount you may get your deductible back. Key Points: Subrogation rights are established in your policy contract. You should not sign any releases with the at-fault party without consulting your insurer. Successful subrogation can result in your deductible being refunded. The process can take several months depending on complexity.

Sample Question: How do I file an auto claim?
Keywords: auto claim, car accident, vehicle claim, car claim, auto accident, car crash, fender bender, collision claim
Answer: To file an auto insurance claim after an accident: 1) Ensure safety and call emergency services if needed. 2) Document the scene with photographs from multiple angles. 3) Exchange information with other drivers (name insurance license plate drivers license). 4) Obtain a police report number if officers respond. 5) Contact your insurance provider within 24 hours. 6) Provide documentation: VIN drivers license description of how the accident occurred. Additional Info: Rental car coverage activates automatically if included in your policy. Total loss is typically declared when repair costs exceed 70-75% of the vehicles actual cash value (ACV). Gap insurance covers the difference between ACV and any outstanding loan balance. Auto claims typically take 10-15 business days to process.

Sample Question: What happens if my car is totaled?
Keywords: total loss, totaled, car totaled, write off, total loss car, vehicle total loss
Answer: A vehicle is declared a total loss when repair costs exceed 70-75% of its Actual Cash Value (ACV). Total Loss Process: 1) Licensed adjuster performs a visual inspection. 2) Repair estimate obtained from an approved body shop. 3) Repair cost compared to the vehicles ACV. 4) If total loss is declared insurer pays ACV minus your deductible. Your Options: Accept the settlement (receive ACV minus deductible insurer takes the vehicle). Retain the salvage (accept a reduced settlement and keep the vehicle). Dispute the value (request an independent appraisal if you disagree with the ACV). Gap insurance is important here — it covers the difference between the ACV payout and any remaining loan/lease balance.

Sample Question: What documents do I need for a claim?
Keywords: document, paperwork, what do i need, required documents, documentation, evidence, submit documents, proof
Answer: Documents typically required for different claim types. All Claims: Policy number and policyholder identification completed claim form photographs of damage written description of the incident. Property Claims: Inventory of damaged/lost items with estimated values receipts or proof of purchase (if available) repair estimates from licensed contractors. Auto Claims: Police report number other drivers information and insurance details vehicle identification number (VIN) repair estimates from approved body shops. Injury Claims: Medical records and bills documentation of lost wages witness statements. Submit all documents promptly — claims processing cannot begin until documentation is complete.

Keywords: settlement, how much, payout, receive, compensation, claim worth, payment, get paid
Answer: Claims settlement depends on the type and extent of the loss. Settlement Methods: Direct payment to the policyholder based on assessed damage value. Payment to repair facilities or service providers. Replacement of the damaged item with an equivalent. Combination of the above methods. Key Factors: Settlement = Assessed Value minus Deductible. For property claims over $10000 an independent appraisal may be required. Payment is issued within 30 days of claim approval. If You Disagree: Request a detailed breakdown of the assessment. Submit an internal appeal within 60 days. Request an independent appraisal for property disputes. Pursue external arbitration if needed.

For auto claims specifically the FNOL process includes additional requirements: Police report number (if applicable). Other drivers insurance information. Photos of vehicle damage and accident scene. Witness contact information. Vehicle Identification Number (VIN). Auto claims typically have a faster initial review (24 hours) due to rental car urgency. Rental car coverage activates automatically if included in your policy.

Sample Question: Can you elaborate on documenting damage?
Keywords: step 3, document, more detail, explain, elaborate, photos, photograph
Answer: Regarding documenting the damage: Take photos from multiple angles in good lighting. Include wide shots showing context and close-ups of damage. Note serial numbers of damaged items. Keep damaged items until the adjuster has reviewed them. Create a written inventory with approximate values and purchase dates. Keep receipts for any emergency repairs or temporary fixes. This documentation is critical as it directly impacts your claim valuation. Digital photos with timestamps are preferred.

Sample Question: How can I speed up my claim?
Keywords: speed up, faster, expedite, hurry, urgent, rush
Answer: To speed up your claims process: 1) Submit complete documentation upfront — incomplete docs are the #1 cause of delays. 2) Respond promptly to adjuster requests (within 24 hours). 3) Use the online portal for document uploads (faster than mail). 4) Get multiple repair estimates proactively. 5) Keep a claims journal with dates names and conversation notes. For urgent situations (uninhabitable home no transportation) ask about expedited processing — emergency claims may qualify for faster timelines.

Keywords: rental, rental car, loaner, transportation, get around
Answer: Regarding rental car coverage after an auto accident: Coverage activates automatically for comprehensive and collision claims (if included in your policy). Typical daily limit: $30-$50/day with a maximum of 30 days. You can rent from any company but approved providers offer direct billing. If the other driver is at fault their insurer may cover your rental costs through subrogation. Check your policy declarations page for your specific rental coverage limits.
